description.en: The course will consist primarily of interactive lectures based on the academic literature which will serve as the basis for structured discussions, designed to help the students both internalize the information and develop a more critical approach. Each class will begin with the instructor introducing and giving an overview of the most significant concepts, theoretical approaches and aspects of the featured theme. The second part of the class will feature a student presentation based on the assigned readings. The presentation(s) will serve as a lead-in to subsequent general class discussion. The discussion will centre on debating a specific proposition or analyzing a specific case in depth. Students are expected to prepare for each class by reading the assigned articles or book chapters and take an active part in the classroom discussion.

objectives.en: This course examines the international relations of the European Union (EU) and explores the EU's quest to become a 'global actor'. The course is in five parts or blocs. The first bloc analyzes the foundations and history of this political project. It examines the main goals of EU foreign policy and key events of crisis when these have failed to be realised. Part two deals with the actors who shape the EU's external relations - the various European institutions and the foreign ministries of the member states - as well as with how policies are crafted and implemented. The third bloc looks at the evolution of and the successes and failures of the EU's Common Foreign and Security Policy and the EU's Common Foreign and Security Policy. Part four examines the other EU's external actions, trade policy, development cooperation, and how the EU has dealt with its own Neighbourhood. The fifth, and final, bloc scrutinizes the EU's attempt to join the ranks of the global powers through various 'strategic partnerships', and the tensions that have defined these political associations. Specifically, the EU's relationship with the US, Russia, China and the United Nations, as well as other multilateral organizations, will be assessed. The overall objective of the course is to critically evaluate the EU's politics on the global stage in terms of what it reveals about the conduct of international relations in the 21st Century.

description.et:
Learning diary: Throughout the course, students will keep a learning diary. In the learning diary, students are going to reflect on reflect on the course contents and/or the literature they have engaged with in preparation for a lecture or seminar. Each entry consists of one or two well-structured paragraphs (around 300 words) in which students (1) identify a specific aspect related to the topic under consideration for reflection; (2) form an independent thought about this topic; (3) develop this thought by providing additional explanation, supporting arguments, examples, comparisons, or (4) by drawing connections to current events; (5) and in which they create links to the course literature. The learning diary is assessed according to:

- clarity and consistency of the argument
- displayed level of critical reflection 
- the sufficiency of sources used and links to the relevant literature

The assessment of the entries to the learning diary is non-differentiated (pass/fail). The learning diary will be weighted at 40% in calculating the final grade.

The final assessment consists of an essay of 2,500- 3,000 words.

The essay component allows students to analyse one important area of EU external relations in considerable depth. Students choose a topic in agreement with the course instructor. For this purpose, they submit a short essay proposal (abstract), which outlines the topic of the essay. The essay topic must be related to the course topics, ideally it should be drawn from the course readings. In the essay, students put forward a proposition (thesis statement) about specific aspect of the EU's role in international politics and provide additional arguments, backed by evidence and examples, in support of this proposition. As well as assessing knowledge of the EU's external relations, the essay component seeks to also assess argument formulation and analytical skills.

Essays must carry full academic reference using a recognized citation style. Further information on what precisely will be expected from students for the essays will be discussed during class time. Students are also strongly encouraged to ask further questions about essays and assessment criteria during the lectures, by email or in person with the lecturer. The essay will be assessed according to:

- the displayed level of familiarity with the institutional framework and policy-making processes of the EU's external relations
- correct and appropriate use of concepts and terminology
- the displayed ability to critically assess the EU's role in international politics in in the light of wider academic debates
- clarity and coherence of structure and consistency of argumentation 
- sufficiency of sources
- adherence to the formal standards of a graduate-level research paper

The assessment of the essay is differentiated (A-F). Late submission of the essay will incur a reduction of the grade by 10%, plus 2% for every additional day of delay. The essay will be weighted at 60% in calculating the final grade.

grade_preconditions.et: Paper submitted by deadline. Plagiarism is not tolerated.

grade_evaluation.et:
Final grade for the course is composed of:
Learning Diary - 40% of the final grade
Essay - 60% of the final grade
